title: 112_s170
content: The Act titled "Helping Responsible Homeowners Act" allows for affordable refinancing of mortgages owned or guaranteed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac. The "Helping Responsible Homeowners Act" defines key terms such as Director, Enterprise, and Qualified mortgage, which includes criteria for a qualified mortgage related to one- to four-family dwellings. The "Helping Responsible Homeowners Act" defines key terms and criteria for qualified mortgages, including one- to four-family dwellings occupied by the mortgagor as their principal residence, owned or guaranteed by specific entities, and with the mortgagor current on payments. A refinancing mortgage is defined as one used to pay off existing mortgage debt. The "Helping Responsible Homeowners Act" outlines criteria for qualified mortgages, including refinancing requirements such as using the new mortgage to pay off existing debt on the same property at a fair interest rate not exceeding 40 basis points above the required net yield. The mortgage for refinancing a qualified mortgage must be on the same property, have a fair interest rate not exceeding 40 basis points above the required net yield, not be limited by loan-to-value ratio, and waive prepayment penalties. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation shall each carry out a program under this section to provide for the refinancing of qualified mortgages. The mortgage shall not be limited by the loan-to-value ratio, waive prepayment penalties, and have a term to maturity of not more than 40 years. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation will refinance qualified mortgages on single-family housing with a term to maturity of up to 40 years. They will purchase or guarantee the refinancing mortgage upon request. Loan level price adjustments and post-settlement are prohibited. The Finance Agency will establish a program requiring Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to purchase or guarantee refinancing mortgages for qualified mortgages. They cannot charge any upfront fees beyond the standard guarantee fee. Servicers holding second liens on qualified mortgages must allow refinancing or face restrictions on originating new mortgages. The program established by the Finance Agency requires Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac to purchase or guarantee refinancing mortgages for qualified mortgages. Servicers holding second liens on qualified mortgages must allow refinancing or face restrictions on originating new mortgages. The requirement for enterprise to refinance qualified mortgages does not apply after one year from the enactment of the Act, but the Director may extend the program at their discretion. The Director may extend the program established under this section for 1-year increments, and regulations necessary for the program will be issued. The Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation must ensure that mortgage servicers inform borrowers about the refinancing program. The Director will include updates on the program in the monthly Foreclosure Prevention & Refinance Report.
